channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: Coronavirus and Reopening: As Governors Urge Caution, G.O.P. Lawmakers Rebel
item.description: In Ohio, a Republican governor is facing an open revolt from members of his own party over whether to keep businesses closed.
item.dc:creator: Campbell Robertson
item.media:credit: Maddie McGarvey for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gabriella Caldwell prepared a flower shop for reopening in Columbus, Ohio, on Thursday. Retail stores in the state will be able to reopen later this month.

item.title: For Latinos and Coronavirus, Doctors are Seeing an ‘Alarming’ Disparity
item.description: The outsized infection rate among Hispanics in some states could hobble efforts to quash the spread of Covid-19, prompting states like Oregon to step up testing and take emergency measures.
item.dc:creator: Miriam Jordan and Richard A. Oppel Jr.
item.media:description: Dr. Eva Galvez, a family physician, tested patients for the coronavirus at a clinic in Hillsboro, Ore.

item.title: Indianapolis Police Fatally Shoot Man Who May Have Streamed Encounter on Facebook Live
item.description: The police said the man was killed after shooting at an officer who chased him for driving recklessly. The man apparently recorded a video several minutes long during the pursuit.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
item.media:description: Indianapolis residents gathered at the scene of a shooting on Wednesday.

item.title: Coronavirus Reopenings: Many Churches Consider Plans to Pray in Person
item.description: Many churches across the country, closed for physical worship for nearly two months, are contemplating what’s next.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Dias
item.media:description: The sun rising behind a church near Commerce, Texas, on May 1. Amid the pandemic, churches in America are wondering how to operate in the longer term.

item.title: U.S. Jobs Report to Offer Clearest Data Yet on Economic Toll: Live Updates
item.description: The latest on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.
item.media:credit: Kim Raff for The New York Times
item.media:description: A worker cleans the City Creek Mall before opening in Salt Lake City on Thursday. The April employment report is expected to reflect big job losses among retail workers.

item.title: Coronavirus World Updates
item.description: The government’s cautious plan puts states and territories in control. A British tracking app is raising privacy concerns.
item.media:description: A public pool that has been closed because of coronavirus restrictions, in Brisbane, Australia, on Friday.

item.title: G.O.P. Coronavirus Message: Economic Crisis Is a Green New Deal Preview
item.description: As the economy melts down, embattled conservatives are testing a political response: saying Democratic climate policies would bring similar pain.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:credit: Bryan Anselm for The New York Times
item.media:description: A shuttered storefront in Newark in March.

item.title: ‘Never Seen Anything Like This’: Experts Question Dropping of Flynn Prosecution
item.description: Abandoning the case is the latest step in a pattern of dismantling the work of the Russia investigators. A former prosecutor likened it to eating the department from the inside out.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.media:description: The case against Michael T. Flynn had become a political cause for President Trump and his supporters.

item.title: Ahmaud Arbery Killing: 2 Suspects Charged With Murder
item.description: Gregory McMichael and Travis McMichael were arrested in connection with the killing of Mr. Arbery, which had led to protests in Georgia.
item.dc:creator: Richard Fausset

item.title: Postal Service Pick With Ties to Trump Raises Concerns Ahead of 2020 Election
item.description: The growing appetite for mail-in voting is adding to worries about the selection of a Republican fund-raiser and Trump donor to be the postmaster general.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:description: Louis DeJoy has been chosen to lead the United States Postal Service at a critical moment.

item.title: The New Culture War
item.description: You’re either a liberal snowflake controlled by big government or a greedy conservative willing to sacrifice Grandma for the economy. It took less than two months for Americans to get here.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer

item.title: F.D.A. Paves Way for Home Testing of Coronavirus
item.description: New findings, scientists say, will speed up the mass production of affordable self-collection kits that can be dropped in the mail.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Jacobs
item.media:credit: Grant Hindsley for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jenni Logue, a research scientist at the University of Washington, demonstrated how to secure a home coronavirus test kit sample for transportation to the lab for results.

item.title: Moderna Gets OK to Start Larger Trial for a Coronavirus Vaccine
item.description: The company announced that the Food and Drug Administration had cleared its application to proceed to a clinical trial involving about 600 people.
item.dc:creator: Knvul Sheikh
item.media:description: Moderna Therapeutics in Cambridge, Mass., in March. It is one of the first biotech companies to begin human trials of an experimental coronavirus vaccine.

item.title: Nearly 20,000 Georgia Teens Are Issued Driver’s Licenses Without a Road Test
item.description: Gov. Brian Kemp suspended the requirement that most Georgians pass a behind-the-wheel test when applying for licenses last month.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:description: Like Georgia, Wisconsin also amended its procedures for issuing new driver’s licenses because of the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: Tara Reade in Megyn Kelly Interview Says Biden Should Withdraw From Presidential Race
item.description: In an interview with Megyn Kelly, Ms. Reade, who has accused Joseph R. Biden Jr. of sexual assault, said he “should not be running on character.” Mr. Biden has denied the allegation.
item.dc:creator: Sydney Ember and Lisa Lerer
item.media:credit: Max Whittaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tara Reade accused Joseph R. Biden Jr. of assaulting her when she was an aide in his Senate office in the early 1990s. He has denied the allegation.

item.title: After Recovery From the Coronavirus, Most People Carry Antibodies
item.description: A new study adds to evidence of immunity among those who have already been exposed to the pathogen.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:description: Taking blood for antibody testing at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan last month.

item.title: Coronavirus Could Disrupt Weather Forecasting
item.description: The amount of atmospheric data routinely gathered by commercial airliners has dropped sharply as a result of the coronavirus, the World Meteorological Organization announced.
item.dc:creator: Henry Fountain
item.media:credit: Frank Rumpenhorst/picture alliance, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Data on temperature, wind and humidity collected by commercial airline flights has fallen sharply.

item.title: This Brooklyn High School Found a Way to Honor Its Graduating Seniors
item.description: With almost all Class of 2020 ceremonies canceled, high schools like James Madison have devised creative methods to celebrate their departing students.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth A. Harris
item.media:description: Martin Philip took a photo on Wednesday of the sign honoring his daughter Jessica, one of the 750 seniors at James Madison High School in Brooklyn, who are being honored on the school’s fence.

item.title: Does the Coronavirus Task Force Even Matter for Trump?
item.description: After saying he would phase out the group, the president now says he will keep it. But he has regularly ignored the information and guidance it has provided.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Maggie Haberman
item.media:description: Until recently, the coronavirus task force’s meeting gave the public health experts a high-profile forum for addressing the public.

item.title: Trump Blocks C.D.C.'s Coronavirus Reopening Guidelines
item.description: Detailed guidelines for reopening drafted by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention were blocked from publication after Trump administration officials labeled them “overly prescriptive.”
item.dc:creator: Abby Goodnough and Maggie Haberman
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Ryan Christopher Jones for The New York Times
item.media:description: Msgr. Guy Massie speaking to an empty church, while streaming his service online, on Easter in Brooklyn.

item.title: Trump’s Pick to Lead Navy Assails Past Leaders and Promises Change
item.description: Kenneth J. Braithwaite, a retired admiral nominated to be the Navy secretary, cited poor leadership in the service’s handling of recent scandals and accidents.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: “Good order and discipline starts with the chain of command,” said Kenneth J. Braithwaite, President Trump’s nominee to be the Navy secretary.

item.title: Sean Reed Shooting: Detective Joked About 'Closed Casket'
item.description: The deaths included two police shootings, one of which was streamed live on Facebook, and an officer fatally striking a pregnant woman with his car.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
item.media:credit: Stevi Kersh/The Indianapolis Star, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Protesters gathered in Indianapolis on Wednesday, hours after a man was killed by the police in a shooting that was captured in part on a Facebook Live video.

item.title: Justice Dept. Drops Case Against Michael Flynn
item.description: The extraordinary move came after the former national security adviser had fought the case in court for months, a reversal after pleading guilty twice and cooperating with investigators.
item.dc:creator: Adam Goldman and Katie Benner
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.media:credit: Samuel Corum for The New York Times
item.media:description: Michael T. Flynn, President Trump’s first national security adviser, pleaded guilty in late 2017 to lying to investigators.

item.title: How Does Antibody Testing Work? We Went Behind the Scenes to Find Out
item.description: Stanford Health Care gave us exclusive access to show how coronavirus antibody testing works. So we followed two caregivers and their blood, through the testing process.
item.dc:creator: Emma Cott, Ben Laffin and Elie Khadra

item.title: Failing to Override a Veto, Senate Falls Short of Curbing Trump’s Iran War Powers
item.description: The defeat of the measure allows President Trump to continue to act unilaterally on Iran, in defiance of Congress.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson
item.media:description: An image of Maj. Gen. Qassim Suleimani of Iran, who was killed by an American airstrike, in Tehran in February.

item.title: Dallas Salon Owner Who Was Jailed for Reopening Is Released
item.description: The salon owner, Shelley Luther, had become a symbol of conservative outrage over state lockdowns and stay-at-home orders.
item.dc:creator: Manny Fernandez and David Montgomery
item.media:description: Shelley Luther, a Dallas hair salon owner who defied an order to keep her business closed, at a rally protesting such restrictions in Frisco, Texas, last month.

item.title: Supreme Court Is Asked to Block House From Seeing Mueller’s Grand Jury Secrets
item.description: The Justice Department asked the justices to temporarily halt a lower-court order, arguing that the executive branch would suffer irreparable harm if the evidence is disclosed.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.media:description: Lawmakers have asked to see secret grand jury evidence gathered by Robert S. Mueller III, the former special counsel.

item.title: May Snow Storm Forecast for the Northeast
item.description: An Arctic blast will sweep parts of the Northeast, bringing record-cold temperatures and even some snow to states that are coming out of a mild winter.
item.dc:creator: Maria Cramer and Henry Fountain
item.media:description: A dusting of snow in Stowe, Vt., on Tuesday. Unseasonably cold weather is expected to move into the Northeast on Friday night.

item.title: Partisan Divide Over Next Coronavirus Stimulus Package
item.description: Democrats hope to extend a program that increased unemployment benefits by $600 a week. Republicans have criticized it as overly generous, creating a disincentive to work.
item.dc:creator: Carl Hulse
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:description: “I think there is going to be a need based on the economic conditions at the end of July for the workers to get an additional boost,” said Senator Ron Wyden, Democrat of Oregon.

item.title: McDonald’s Employee Is Shot After Store Is Partly Closed for Coronavirus
item.description: At least four employees were injured after one told a woman that the dining area was closed, the police said.
item.dc:creator: Mihir Zaveri
item.media:description: The police responding to a shooting at a McDonald’s in southwest Oklahoma City on Wednesday.

item.title: U.S. Military Killed 132 Civilians in Wars Last Year, Pentagon Says
item.description: The tally has changed little since the previous year’s report, which put the total at 120 civilians killed. Civilian deaths in Afghanistan again eclipsed those in Syria and Iraq.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: An American military vehicle at Bagram Air Field in Afghanistan last year.

item.title: Supreme Court Unanimously Overturns ‘Bridgegate’ Convictions
item.description: The court said there was evidence of “wrongdoing” by two associates of Chris Christie, the former New Jersey governor, but no federal crime.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak and Nick Corasaniti
item.category: Port Authority of New York and New Jersey
item.media:credit: Bryan Anselm for The New York Times
item.media:description: Bridget Anne Kelly and Bill Baroni leaving a federal courthouse in Newark, N.J., in 2016.

item.title: Government Orders Alone Didn’t Close the Economy. They Probably Can’t Reopen It.
item.description: Data shows there was a drop in spending and working even before any official mandates to stay at home.
item.dc:creator: Emily Badger and Alicia Parlapiano
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)

item.title: Generic Drug Maker Admits to Fixing Prices for Cholesterol Medication
item.description: For conspiring to inflate drug prices, Apotex will pay $24 million and cooperate with the Justice Department’s investigation into the pharmaceutical industry.
item.dc:creator: Katie Benner
item.media:description: Apotex’s manufacturing plant in Toronto.

item.title: Wildfires in Florida Force Hundreds to Evacuate: ‘All You Could See Is Smoke’
item.description: More than 1,000 residents were told to move away from fires that a state official called “extremely dangerous.”
item.dc:creator: Christine Hauser
item.media:credit: Florida Department of Agriculture and Consumer Services, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The fire broke out on Monday afternoon and has grown, fanned by high winds and low humidity, officials said.

item.title: Unemployment in California: When Will You Get Benefit Payments?
item.description: Thursday: Millions have applied for unemployment insurance in California. Here’s what you need to know now. Also: Find a testing site near you.
item.dc:creator: Marie Tae McDermott and Jill Cowan
item.media:credit: Frederic J. Brown/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A woman entering a building where the Employment Development Department has its offices in Los Angeles on Tuesday.

item.title: On Politics: Rising Hunger as the Virus’s Effects Spread
item.description: Grim evidence of a virus’s continuing toll as the country reopens: This is your morning tip sheet.
item.dc:creator: Giovanni Russonello

item.title: Coronavirus, President Trump, India: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Janie Osborne for The New York Times
item.media:description: A coal-fired generating station in Sidney, Mont.

item.title: Live Coronavirus News Updates
item.description: President Trump’s travel restrictions led to an exodus from hot spots, but little rigorous testing. Another 3.2 million people filed for unemployment benefits.

item.title: Knock, Knock, Who’s There? No Political Canvassers, for the First Time Maybe Ever
item.description: Candidates and political parties are struggling to plan for a fall campaign without some of the most basic building blocks of politics.
item.dc:creator: Shane Goldmacher
item.media:credit: Jordan Gale for The New York Times
item.media:description: A sign for former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. was left on a door by a canvasser in Dubuque, Iowa, in January. Showing up on doorsteps has long been one of the most reliable ways to get people to vote.

item.title: As Restaurants Remain Shuttered, American Cities Fear the Future
item.description: Restaurants have become the economic lifeblood for many cities. The coronavirus threatens to take away more than just delicious food.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Steinhauer and Pete Wells
item.media:credit: Whitney Curtis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Olio, an Italian restaurant in St. Louis, was converted from an old gas station.

item.title: His Day Job: Cory Booker’s Top Aide. His Night One: E.M.S. Volunteer.
item.description: When coronavirus cases rose in New Jersey, Matt Klapper, a former firefighter and ambulance crew chief, answered a call for retired medical workers to help out.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer
item.media:credit: Bryan Anselm for The New York Times
item.media:description: Matt Klapper, the chief of staff for Senator Cory Booker, pulled an ambulance into the bay at the squad dispatch in Springfield, N.J., last week.

item.title: Travel From New York City Seeded Wave of U.S. Outbreaks
item.description: The coronavirus outbreak in New York City became the primary source of infections around the United States, researchers have found.
item.dc:creator: Benedict Carey and James Glanz

item.title: UnitedHealth Customers Will See a Discount on Next Month’s Bill
item.description: The insurer has seen its earnings rise during the pandemic, so it’s awarding premium credits to people enrolled in its plans.
item.dc:creator: Reed Abelson
item.media:description: UnitedHealth Group has decided to return a part of its profits during the pandemic to enrollees.
